item.title: Sailing the Adriatic: A seasonal analysis of lightning patterns
item.author: Unknown
item.description:
The Adriatic Sea is a dream destination for sailors with stunning coastlines, historic towns, and clear water. However, anyone who has spent a summer in Croatia knows the other side of the coin: Sudden, violent thunderstorms (Neverins) are a real threat.

After a lightning strike hit right next to our boat in Greece, we built IncusGrid to stop guessing and start analyzing. We processed billions of historical data points combined with terrain topography to understand where the real risks lie.

Here is what the data tells us about the lightning season in the Adriatic.

The Season Begins: June

While May and early June are generally considered safe, lightning activity starts to pick up by the end of June. Interestingly, this is mostly confined to the Northern Adriatic (Gulf of Trieste), while the south remains relatively calm.

The Peak: July & Local Variations

By July, the heat is on. The Gulf of Trieste turns purple on our heatmap. But look closer at the Croatian coast: There are notable local variations.

The regions around Senj, Novalja, and Split show significantly higher lightning density compared to the relatively calmer areas around Zadar and Šibenik.

Pro Tip: If you seek calm nights in July, the data suggests the Zadar archipelago might be a statistically safer bet than the bustling (and electric) region around Split.

The Contrast: The Ionian Sea

It is also interesting to zoom out. While the Northern Adriatic cooks, the Ionian Sea (south of Albania) remains surprisingly calm during July, making it a potentially safer alternative for those looking to avoid the peak thunderstorm season.

High Season: August

In August, the picture intensifies. The hotspot moves south. We see a new high-activity zone emerging from Makarska down to Zaljev Budima.

Finding Safety: The Power of Terrain Shielding

This is where route planning becomes crucial. Even in active zones, terrain matters.

Look at the islands of Lopud and Koločep near Dubrovnik. Using the IncusGrid Exposure Layer, we can identify the bay of Uvala Sunj as a statistically safer anchorage.

Why? The brighter coloring in IncusGrid indicates strong terrain shielding. The steep hills surrounding the bay provide a theoretical "shadow zone" against lightning strikes, offering significantly better protection compared to bays with flat terrain.

Late Season: The Flip (September - November)

As autumn approaches, the Ionian Sea wakes up. Activity increases around Corfu and Zakynthos.

By October and November, the pattern completely flips: The Adriatic becomes calm again, while the heavy lightning activity shifts south to Albania and Greece.

Plan your own route

These are general seasonal trends, but every region is different.

Are you planning a charter or a cruise in the Adriatic? Don't rely on luck. Check your specific anchorages on IncusGrid to see if you are dropping your hook in a safe zone or a lightning magnet.

Stay safe and fair winds! ⛵️⚡️

item.title: Why We Built IncusGrid: From Lightning Strike to Safety Tool
item.author: Unknown
item.description:
Last October, our family was sailing the Ionian Sea when we sheltered in the bay of Igoumenitsa, Greece, to avoid an approaching storm. While we were very protected from the wind and waves, we experienced a lightning strike right next to our boat. It damaged our electronics and left us shaken.

Ever since, we've asked ourselves: What are our chances of being struck by lightning at this location? Would we be safer on the east side of the bay or on the west side? How much does the surrounding terrain protect us from lightning strikes?

What is IncusGrid?

Weather apps predict when a lightning storm is approaching. IncusGrid combines historical data with local terrain features to show you where you are statistically safest from lightning strikes.

Lightning strikes are chaotic and cannot be predicted with certainty. The lightning strike that hit the water next to our boat could have just as well hit our boat directly. Just like wearing a seatbelt doesn't guarantee survival but significantly improves your odds, choosing the right anchorage can reduce your lightning risk.

This might mean avoiding a specific region during a specific time of the year or choosing the side of a bay that is better protected by surrounding terrain. IncusGrid helps you make these decisions based on data.

Topography analysis

When high buildings or technical facilities are built, a so-called rolling sphere method is often used to determine which parts of the building need additional lightning protection. Applying this method identifies areas that are naturally protected by surrounding terrain features.

IncusGrid applies a similar analysis to calculate how well terrain features protect different locations from lightning strikes.

We expose this analysis through our "Exposure" layer, which already covers most parts of the world.

Historical lightning patterns

In addition to terrain shielding, IncusGrid analyzes billions of historical lightning strikes captured by satellites over recent years. Our "Activity" layer shows the average lightning strikes per square kilometer for any given month or over the entire year. This layer helps identify how lightning activity varies throughout the year and across different regions.

More to come

IncusGrid is continuously evolving. We are working on integrating more satellite data sources to improve coverage and accuracy. We are also developing new features that visualize fascinating lightning data that traditional weather apps do not provide.

Looking back at that night in Igoumenitsa, IncusGrid now shows us that the southern shore would have offered better terrain shielding. We can't change the past, but we can make better decisions in the future.

Ready to explore lightning patterns in your cruising area? Open IncusGrid and see for yourself.
